description: Comprehensive interview questions database for QA Automation Engineers based on Indian job market research

questions.question: Explain the difference between == and .equals() in Java
questions.answer: == compares object references (memory addresses), while .equals() compares object values/content. For primitive types, == compares values. For objects, == checks if both references point to the same object in memory, whereas .equals() (when properly overridden) checks if the objects have the same content.
followUp: What is the String pool in Java?
How do you override equals() method correctly?

questions.question: What is the difference between String, StringBuilder, and StringBuffer?
questions.answer: String is immutable (cannot be changed once created). StringBuilder is mutable and not thread-safe (faster). StringBuffer is mutable and thread-safe (slower due to synchronization). Use String for simple operations, StringBuilder for single-threaded string manipulation, and StringBuffer for multi-threaded environments.
followUp: Why is String immutable in Java?
What is the performance difference between StringBuilder and StringBuffer?

questions.question: Explain HashMap internal working and collision handling
questions.answer: HashMap uses array of buckets with linked lists/trees for collision handling. Hash function determines bucket index. Collisions resolved via chaining (linked list until Java 7, balanced tree from Java 8 when chain length > 8). Load factor 0.75 triggers resizing to maintain performance.
followUp: What happens during HashMap resizing?
Explain ConcurrentHashMap vs HashMap

questions.question: Explain Java 8 Stream API with practical examples
questions.answer: Stream API enables functional-style operations on collections. Provides operations like filter, map, reduce, collect. Streams are lazy (intermediate operations executed only when terminal operation called), support parallel processing, and don't modify original collection.
followUp: What are intermediate vs terminal operations?
Explain flatMap with example

questions.question: What is Optional class and how does it prevent NullPointerException?
questions.answer: Optional is a container that may or may not contain a value. It forces explicit null checks and provides methods like isPresent(), orElse(), orElseGet(), orElseThrow(). Prevents NPE by making null handling explicit and encouraging better coding practices.
followUp: When would you use orElse vs orElseGet?
Can Optional contain null value?

questions.question: Explain functional interfaces and lambda expressions in Java 8
questions.answer: Functional interfaces have exactly one abstract method (SAM - Single Abstract Method). Lambda expressions provide concise way to implement functional interfaces. Common types: Predicate<T> (boolean test), Consumer<T> (void accept), Supplier<T> (T get), Function<T,R> (R apply).
followUp: What are method references?
Can lambda expressions access local variables?

questions.question: Explain memory management in Java - Heap vs Stack
questions.answer: Stack stores method call frames, local variables, partial results. Each thread has own stack. Heap stores objects and instance variables. Heap divided into Young Generation (Eden, S0, S1) and Old Generation. Garbage collector manages heap memory automatically.
followUp: What are different types of garbage collectors?
How do you identify memory leaks?

questions.question: What are design patterns? Explain Singleton, Factory, and Observer patterns
questions.answer: Design patterns are reusable solutions to common problems. Singleton ensures single instance, Factory creates objects without specifying exact class, Observer defines one-to-many dependency between objects so when one changes, all dependents are notified.
followUp: What is dependency injection?
Explain Builder pattern with example

questions.question: Explain multithreading and thread synchronization in Java
questions.answer: Multithreading allows concurrent execution. Thread lifecycle: New → Runnable → Running → Blocked/Waiting/Timed_Waiting → Terminated. Synchronization prevents thread interference using synchronized keyword, locks, or atomic classes. ExecutorService manages thread pools efficiently.
followUp: What is deadlock and how to prevent it?
Explain volatile keyword

questions.question: What is reflection in Java and when would you use it?
questions.answer: Reflection allows examining and modifying runtime behavior of classes, methods, and fields. Used in frameworks (Spring, Hibernate), testing, serialization, and dependency injection. Performance overhead exists, so use judiciously.
followUp: What are annotations and how are they processed?
Explain proxy pattern using reflection

questions.question: What are the basic data types in Java?
questions.answer: Java has 8 primitive data types: byte (8-bit), short (16-bit), int (32-bit), long (64-bit), float (32-bit), double (64-bit), char (16-bit), and boolean. These are stored directly in memory and are not objects. Non-primitive types include String, Arrays, and Classes.
questions.code:
// Primitive data types
byte b = 127;           // -128 to 127
short s = 32767;        // -32,768 to 32,767
int i = 2147483647;     // -2^31 to 2^31-1
long l = 9223372036854775807L;  // -2^63 to 2^63-1

float f = 3.14f;        // 32-bit floating point
double d = 3.14159;     // 64-bit floating point

char c = 'A';           // Single character
boolean flag = true;    // true or false

// Non-primitive types
String str = "Hello";   // Object type
int[] arr = {1, 2, 3};  // Array type
followUp: What is the difference between int and Integer?
What happens if you exceed the range of a data type?

questions.question: What is the difference between public, private, protected, and default access modifiers?
questions.answer: Access modifiers control visibility: public (accessible everywhere), private (only within same class), protected (same package + subclasses), default/package-private (only within same package). They help in encapsulation and data hiding.
followUp: What is encapsulation?
Can a class be private in Java?

questions.question: What are the four pillars of Object-Oriented Programming?
questions.answer: The four pillars are: 1) Encapsulation (bundling data and methods, data hiding), 2) Inheritance (is-a relationship, code reusability), 3) Polymorphism (one interface, multiple implementations), 4) Abstraction (hiding implementation details, showing only essential features).
followUp: What is the difference between abstract class and interface?
Give a real-world example of polymorphism

questions.question: What is a constructor in Java? What are the types of constructors?
questions.answer: Constructor is a special method used to initialize objects. It has the same name as the class and no return type. Types: 1) Default Constructor (no parameters), 2) Parameterized Constructor (with parameters), 3) Copy Constructor (not directly supported, but can be implemented).
followUp: Can a constructor be private?
What is constructor chaining?

questions.question: What is method overloading and method overriding?
questions.answer: Method Overloading: Same method name with different parameters in the same class (compile-time polymorphism). Method Overriding: Child class provides specific implementation of parent class method with same signature (runtime polymorphism).
followUp: Can we overload static methods?
What is the @Override annotation?

questions.question: What are loops in Java? Explain for, while, and do-while loops.
questions.answer: Loops execute code repeatedly. for loop: known number of iterations. while loop: executes while condition is true (checks condition first). do-while loop: executes at least once (checks condition after execution). Enhanced for loop (for-each) for arrays and collections.
companies: All IT companies for basic programming
followUp: What is the difference between break and continue?
When would you use a do-while loop?

questions.question: What are arrays in Java? How do you declare and initialize arrays?
questions.answer: Arrays are objects that store multiple values of the same type in contiguous memory. They have fixed size and zero-based indexing. Can be single-dimensional or multi-dimensional. Arrays are reference types in Java.
followUp: What happens if you access an array out of bounds?
How do you find the length of an array?

questions.question: What is the difference between if-else and switch statements?
questions.answer: if-else: Used for complex conditions, supports any boolean expression, can handle ranges. switch: Used for discrete values, works with int, char, String, enum, more readable for multiple fixed values, uses break to prevent fall-through.
companies: All companies for basic programming logic
followUp: What happens if you forget break in switch?
Can you use switch with boolean?

questions.question: What is the main method in Java? Why is it static?
questions.answer: main method is the entry point of Java applications. Signature: public static void main(String[] args). It's static because JVM needs to call it without creating an object. public: accessible by JVM, void: returns nothing, args: command-line arguments.
followUp: Can we overload the main method?
What happens if main method is not static?

questions.question: What is the difference between static and non-static methods?
questions.answer: Static methods belong to the class, not to any specific instance. Can be called without creating objects. Cannot access instance variables directly. Non-static methods belong to instances, need object creation to call, can access both static and non-static members.
followUp: What is a static block?
Can we override static methods?

questions.question: What are packages in Java? How do you import and use them?
questions.answer: Packages are namespaces that organize related classes and interfaces. They prevent naming conflicts, provide access protection, and make searching easier. Use 'package' keyword to declare and 'import' to use classes from other packages.
followUp: What is the difference between import and static import?
What happens if two packages have classes with the same name?

questions.question: What is exception handling in Java? Explain try-catch-finally.
questions.answer: Exception handling manages runtime errors gracefully. try block contains code that might throw exceptions, catch block handles exceptions, finally block executes regardless of exception occurrence. Types: Checked exceptions (compile-time) and Unchecked exceptions (runtime).
followUp: What is the difference between throw and throws?
What are checked and unchecked exceptions?

questions.question: What are the basic collection classes in Java? Explain ArrayList, LinkedList, and HashMap.
questions.answer: Collections framework provides data structures. ArrayList: dynamic array, fast random access, slow insertion/deletion in middle. LinkedList: doubly-linked list, fast insertion/deletion, slow random access. HashMap: key-value pairs, O(1) average access time.
followUp: When would you choose LinkedList over ArrayList?
What is the difference between HashMap and Hashtable?

questions.question: What are interfaces in Java? How are they different from classes?
questions.answer: Interfaces define contracts that classes must implement. They contain abstract methods (and default/static methods from Java 8). Classes can implement multiple interfaces but extend only one class. Interfaces achieve multiple inheritance and loose coupling.
followUp: Can interfaces have constructors?
What are marker interfaces?

questions.question: What is inheritance in Java? Explain with an example.
questions.answer: Inheritance allows a class to inherit properties and methods from another class. Child class (subclass) extends parent class (superclass). Enables code reusability and establishes is-a relationship. Java supports single inheritance for classes.
followUp: What is the super keyword?
Can a class extend multiple classes in Java?

questions.question: What are wrapper classes in Java? Why are they needed?
questions.answer: Wrapper classes provide object representation of primitive data types. Needed for collections (which only work with objects), null values, utility methods, and when primitives need to behave as objects. Java provides autoboxing and unboxing.
followUp: What is autoboxing and unboxing?
What is the Integer cache in Java?

questions.question: What is the this keyword in Java? When and why is it used?
questions.answer: 'this' is a reference to the current object instance. Used to distinguish between instance variables and parameters with same names, call other constructors in the same class, pass current object as parameter, and improve code readability.
followUp: Can you use 'this' in static methods?
What is the difference between 'this' and 'super'?

questions.question: What are variables in Java? Explain local, instance, and static variables.
questions.answer: Variables store data. Local variables: declared inside methods, exist only during method execution. Instance variables: belong to objects, each object has its own copy. Static variables: belong to class, shared among all objects, initialized when class is first loaded.
followUp: What is variable shadowing?
What happens if you don't initialize local variables?

questions.question: What is the final keyword in Java? Where can it be used?
questions.answer: final keyword makes entities unchangeable. final variables: constants (cannot be reassigned), final methods: cannot be overridden, final classes: cannot be extended (like String). Provides immutability and prevents inheritance/modification.
companies: All companies using Java constants and immutable objects
followUp: What is the difference between final, finally, and finalize?
Can final variables be null?

questions.question: What is the toString() method in Java? How do you override it?
questions.answer: toString() method returns string representation of an object. Inherited from Object class, default implementation returns className@hashCode. Should be overridden to provide meaningful string representation for debugging and logging.
companies: All companies requiring object debugging and logging
followUp: When is toString() automatically called?
What's the relationship between toString() and String concatenation?

questions.question: What are Java annotations and how do you create custom annotations?
questions.answer: Annotations are metadata that provide information about code to compiler, runtime, or development tools. Built-in annotations include @Override, @Deprecated, @SuppressWarnings. Custom annotations use @interface keyword and meta-annotations like @Retention, @Target, @Documented.
followUp: What are meta-annotations?
How do annotations work with Spring framework?

questions.question: What is exception handling in Java? Explain checked vs unchecked exceptions.
questions.answer: Exception handling manages runtime errors using try-catch-finally blocks. Checked exceptions (compile-time) must be caught or declared (IOException, SQLException). Unchecked exceptions (runtime) don't require explicit handling (NullPointerException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException). Finally block always executes.

questions.question: What is Selenium WebDriver and how is it different from Selenium RC?
questions.answer: Selenium WebDriver is a web automation tool that directly communicates with browsers through browser-specific drivers. Unlike Selenium RC which used JavaScript injection and a server, WebDriver uses browser's native support, making it faster, more reliable, and doesn't require a separate server.
companies: All companies hiring for automation roles
followUp: What are the components of Selenium Suite?
Advantages of Selenium over other tools?

questions.question: Explain all 8 locator strategies in Selenium with examples
questions.answer: 1) ID: Most preferred, unique identifier. 2) Name: Using name attribute. 3) Class Name: CSS class. 4) Tag Name: HTML tag. 5) Link Text: Exact link text. 6) Partial Link Text: Partial match. 7) CSS Selector: CSS pattern. 8) XPath: XML path expression. Priority: ID > Name > CSS > XPath
followUp: When to use CSS vs XPath?
How to handle dynamic locators?

questions.question: Explain different types of waits in Selenium and when to use each
questions.answer: 1) Implicit Wait: Global timeout for element finding (not recommended). 2) Explicit Wait: Wait for specific condition with WebDriverWait. 3) Fluent Wait: Explicit wait with polling interval and ignored exceptions. Best practice: Use Explicit/Fluent waits for better control and reliability.
followUp: What are custom Expected Conditions?
Why avoid Thread.sleep()?

questions.question: How do you handle JavaScript execution and AJAX calls in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use JavascriptExecutor to execute JavaScript code, handle AJAX with custom waits for jQuery.active === 0 or XMLHttpRequest readyState === 4. Can execute scripts synchronously or asynchronously. Useful for scrolling, clicking hidden elements, getting page properties.
followUp: How to handle asynchronous JavaScript?
What's the difference between executeScript and executeAsyncScript?

questions.question: How do you handle Shadow DOM elements in Selenium?
questions.answer: Shadow DOM encapsulates DOM tree from main document. Use JavascriptExecutor to access shadow root, then find elements within shadow tree. Regular Selenium locators don't work directly on shadow DOM elements. Need to traverse shadow boundaries explicitly.
followUp: What are the challenges with Shadow DOM testing?
How do you handle closed shadow roots?

questions.question: Explain Page Object Model (POM) and Page Factory pattern
questions.answer: POM separates page elements and actions into classes. Page Factory initializes WebElements using @FindBy annotations and PageFactory.initElements(). Provides lazy initialization, caching, and clean separation. Improves maintainability and reusability of automation code.
followUp: What's the difference between POM and Page Factory?
How do you handle dynamic elements in POM?

questions.question: How do you implement parallel execution with ThreadLocal WebDriver?
questions.answer: ThreadLocal creates separate WebDriver instance per thread, ensuring thread safety during parallel execution. Each thread maintains its own driver copy. Use with TestNG parallel execution and Selenium Grid for cross-browser testing.
followUp: How do you handle shared test data in parallel execution?
What are the challenges with parallel testing?

questions.question: How do you set up Selenium WebDriver for different browsers?
questions.answer: Selenium WebDriver requires browser-specific driver executables. Use WebDriverManager for automatic driver management or download drivers manually. Set system properties or use ChromeOptions, FirefoxOptions for browser configuration.
followUp: What is WebDriverManager and why use it?
How do you run tests in headless mode?

questions.question: What is the difference between driver.get() and driver.navigate().to()?
questions.answer: driver.get() loads a new web page and waits for it to load completely. driver.navigate().to() also navigates to URL but provides additional navigation methods like back(), forward(), refresh(). Functionally similar for basic navigation.
followUp: When would you use navigate() over get()?
What happens if navigation fails?

questions.question: How do you handle basic browser window operations in Selenium?
questions.answer: Selenium provides methods to manage browser windows: maximize(), minimize(), fullscreen(), get window size/position, set window size/position. These help in creating consistent test environments across different screen sizes.
followUp: How do you switch between multiple browser windows?
What's the difference between window handle and window title?

questions.question: Explain the WebElement interface and common methods used with it.
questions.answer: WebElement represents an HTML element on the page. Common methods: click(), sendKeys(), getText(), getAttribute(), isDisplayed(), isEnabled(), isSelected(), clear(). These methods allow interaction and information gathering from web elements.
followUp: What happens if you call methods on stale elements?
How do you handle elements that are not immediately visible?

questions.question: How do you handle basic form interactions in Selenium?
questions.answer: Form interactions include filling text fields with sendKeys(), selecting options from dropdowns using Select class, clicking checkboxes and radio buttons, and submitting forms with submit() or click(). Clear fields before entering new data.
followUp: How do you verify form validation messages?
What's the difference between click() and submit()?

questions.question: What are the different types of alerts in Selenium and how do you handle them?
questions.answer: Three types of alerts: Simple alert (OK button), Confirmation alert (OK/Cancel), Prompt alert (text input + OK/Cancel). Handle using driver.switchTo().alert() to get Alert interface, then accept(), dismiss(), or getText().
followUp: What happens if you try to interact with page while alert is present?
How do you handle unexpected alerts during test execution?

questions.question: How do you capture screenshots in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use TakesScreenshot interface to capture screenshots. Cast WebDriver to TakesScreenshot, call getScreenshotAs() method, and save to file using FileUtils or Files. Useful for debugging test failures and creating reports.
followUp: How do you integrate screenshots in test reports?
What's the difference between full page and viewport screenshots?

questions.question: What are different ways to find multiple elements in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use findElements() (plural) instead of findElement() to find multiple matching elements. Returns List<WebElement>. Useful for handling tables, lists, menus, or any repeated elements. Empty list returned if no elements found.
companies: All automation companies dealing with dynamic content
followUp: How do you handle dynamic lists that change during test execution?
What's the performance difference between findElement and findElements?

questions.question: How do you handle basic iframe interactions in Selenium?
questions.answer: Iframes are separate HTML documents within the main document. Use driver.switchTo().frame() to switch context to iframe, perform actions, then switch back to default content using driver.switchTo().defaultContent() or parentFrame().
companies: Companies testing embedded content and widgets
followUp: How do you identify if an element is inside an iframe?
What happens if you don't switch back from an iframe?

questions.question: How do you work with browser cookies in Selenium?
questions.answer: Selenium provides methods to manage cookies through driver.manage().getCookies(), addCookie(), deleteCookie(), deleteAllCookies(). Useful for testing login sessions, user preferences, and maintaining state across test scenarios.
companies: E-commerce and web applications with user sessions
followUp: How do you save and restore cookies between test sessions?
How do cookies affect test isolation?

questions.question: What are the basic timeouts in Selenium and how do you configure them?
questions.answer: Three main timeouts: Implicit Wait (global element search timeout), Page Load Timeout (page loading timeout), Script Timeout (JavaScript execution timeout). Configure using driver.manage().timeouts() methods. Implicit waits are global but not recommended for complex scenarios.
followUp: What's the difference between implicit wait and explicit wait?
How do timeouts affect test performance?

questions.question: How do you perform keyboard actions in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use Actions class for complex keyboard interactions like key combinations, special keys (Tab, Enter, Escape), and modifier keys (Ctrl, Alt, Shift). sendKeys() method on WebElement handles basic text input. Actions provide more control over keyboard behavior.
companies: All automation companies testing keyboard shortcuts
followUp: How do you handle different keyboard layouts?
What's the difference between sendKeys on element vs Actions?

questions.question: How do you handle basic mouse actions in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use Actions class for mouse operations: click(), doubleClick(), rightClick(), moveToElement() for hover, dragAndDrop() for drag operations. Actions provide precise control over mouse movements and interactions beyond basic click().
followUp: How do you handle drag and drop with HTML5?
What's the difference between click() on WebElement vs Actions?

questions.question: How do you verify element presence and visibility in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use isDisplayed(), isEnabled(), isSelected() methods on WebElement to check element state. For presence checking, use try-catch with findElement() or findElements().size() > 0. NoSuchElementException thrown if element not found.
followUp: What's the difference between element presence and visibility?
How do you wait for an element to become visible?

questions.question: How do you get text content and attributes from web elements?
questions.answer: Use getText() to get visible text content, getAttribute() to get HTML attributes, getCssValue() to get CSS properties. getText() returns empty string for hidden elements. getAttribute() can access standard and custom HTML attributes.
followUp: How do you handle elements with dynamic attributes?
What's the difference between getText() and textContent?

questions.question: How do you handle file upload and download in Selenium WebDriver?
questions.answer: For file upload, use sendKeys() with input[type='file'] elements to provide file path. For file download, configure browser preferences to specify download location and disable download prompts. Use AutoIT or Robot class for complex file dialog handling.
followUp: How do you handle drag-and-drop file uploads?
What are the limitations of WebDriver for file operations?

questions.question: How do you handle alerts, pop-ups, and modal dialogs in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use Alert interface to handle JavaScript alerts. switchTo().alert() gets alert reference. Methods: accept() (OK), dismiss() (Cancel), getText() (get text), sendKeys() (enter text). For modal dialogs, treat as regular elements within the page DOM.
companies: All web applications with interactive elements
followUp: How do you handle browser-specific authentication dialogs?
What's the difference between alerts and modal dialogs?

questions.question: How do you handle frames and iframes in Selenium WebDriver?
questions.answer: Use switchTo().frame() to switch context to frames/iframes. Can switch by index, name/id, or WebElement. Must switch back to default content using switchTo().defaultContent() to access main page elements. Nested frames require sequential switching.
followUp: How do you handle frames that load dynamically?
What's the difference between iframe and frame elements?

questions.question: How do you perform drag and drop operations in Selenium WebDriver?
questions.answer: Use Actions class for drag and drop operations. Methods: dragAndDrop(source, target), clickAndHold(), moveToElement(), release(). Can drag by offset using dragAndDropBy(). Build action chain with build().perform(). Useful for sortable lists, file uploads, and UI customization.
followUp: How do you handle HTML5 drag and drop events?
What are the common issues with drag and drop in different browsers?

questions.question: How do you set up Selenium WebDriver in Java? Explain the basic setup steps.
questions.answer: 1) Download and add Selenium WebDriver JAR files to project, 2) Download browser drivers (ChromeDriver, GeckoDriver), 3) Set system property for driver path, 4) Create WebDriver instance, 5) Use WebDriverManager for automatic driver management.
followUp: What is WebDriverManager?
How do you handle different browser versions?

questions.question: What are the basic navigation methods in Selenium WebDriver?
questions.answer: Basic navigation methods include: driver.get() to load URL, driver.navigate().back() for previous page, driver.navigate().forward() for next page, driver.navigate().refresh() to reload page, driver.getCurrentUrl() to get current URL.
followUp: What's the difference between driver.get() and navigate().to()?
How do you handle page loading issues?

questions.question: How do you find and interact with text input fields in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use findElement() with locators to find input fields, then use sendKeys() to enter text, clear() to remove text, and getAttribute("value") to get text. Always clear field before entering new text for reliability.
followUp: How do you handle different input types?
What are best practices for text input validation?

questions.question: How do you handle button clicks in Selenium WebDriver?
questions.answer: Use click() method on WebElement to click buttons. First find the button using locators (id, name, xpath, css). Check if button is enabled using isEnabled(). Use Actions class for complex click scenarios.
followUp: How do you handle disabled buttons?
What's the difference between click() and submit()?

questions.question: How do you handle dropdown/select elements in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use Select class from Selenium support package to handle dropdown elements. Methods: selectByVisibleText(), selectByValue(), selectByIndex(), getOptions(), getFirstSelectedOption(). Only works with <select> HTML elements.
followUp: How do you handle custom dropdowns?
What's the difference between single and multi-select?

questions.question: How do you handle checkboxes and radio buttons in Selenium?
questions.answer: Use click() to select/deselect checkboxes and radio buttons. Use isSelected() to check current state. For checkboxes: can select multiple. For radio buttons: only one can be selected in a group.
followUp: How do you handle custom styled checkboxes?
What's the difference between radio buttons and checkboxes?

questions.question: What is REST API? Explain HTTP methods and status codes
questions.answer: REST (Representational State Transfer) is architectural style for web services. HTTP Methods: GET (retrieve), POST (create), PUT (update/replace), PATCH (partial update), DELETE (remove). Status Codes: 2xx (success), 3xx (redirection), 4xx (client error), 5xx (server error). Common: 200 OK, 201 Created, 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found, 500 Internal Server Error.

fintechCompanies.note: API testing critical for financial transactions

followUp: What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
Explain idempotency in REST

questions.question: How do you perform JSON validation and extraction in REST Assured?
questions.answer: REST Assured provides JsonPath for JSON validation and extraction. Use body() for assertions, jsonPath() for extraction, and hamcrest matchers for validation. Can validate response structure, specific fields, arrays, nested objects. Schema validation ensures response matches JSON schema.
followUp: How do you handle dynamic JSON values?
Explain JSON Schema validation

questions.question: How do you handle authentication in API testing (OAuth, JWT, API Keys)?
questions.answer: REST Assured supports multiple authentication methods: Basic Auth (username:password Base64 encoded), Bearer Token (JWT in Authorization header), API Key (in headers or query params), OAuth 2.0 (token-based). Use .auth() method or manually add headers. For OAuth, implement token generation flow.
followUp: How do you handle token refresh?
Explain OAuth 2.0 flow

questions.question: What is API Contract Testing and how is it different from functional testing?
questions.answer: Contract testing ensures API consumer and provider agree on API contract (request/response format). Uses consumer-driven contracts (CDC) where consumer defines expectations. Pact framework is popular. Different from functional testing which validates business logic. Contract testing validates interface compatibility, especially important in microservices.
followUp: When should you use contract testing?
Explain Pact Broker role

questions.question: How do you implement RequestSpecification and ResponseSpecification in REST Assured?
questions.answer: RequestSpecification defines reusable request configuration (base URI, headers, authentication, content type). ResponseSpecification defines expected response validations (status code, content type, response time). Both promote DRY principle and reduce code duplication. Use RequestSpecBuilder and ResponseSpecBuilder for creation.
followUp: How do you implement API test framework architecture?
Explain filters in REST Assured

questions.question: How do you handle file uploads and downloads in API testing?
questions.answer: For file uploads, use multiPart() method with REST Assured to send files as form data. For downloads, capture response as byte array or stream. Handle different content types and validate file integrity. Important for testing document management, image processing, and data import/export APIs.
followUp: How do you validate file content after upload?
How to handle large file uploads?

questions.question: What is an API and what are the different types of APIs?
questions.answer: API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate with each other. Types include: Web APIs (HTTP-based), REST APIs (architectural style), SOAP APIs (protocol), GraphQL APIs, and Internal APIs (within organization).
followUp: What is the difference between API and web service?
What are the benefits of using APIs?

questions.question: Explain HTTP request methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) with examples
questions.answer: HTTP methods define the action to be performed. GET retrieves data (safe, idempotent), POST creates new resources, PUT updates/replaces entire resource (idempotent), DELETE removes resources (idempotent). Each method has specific use cases and behavior.
followUp: What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
Which HTTP methods are idempotent?

questions.question: What are HTTP status codes? Explain common ones with examples
questions.answer: HTTP status codes indicate the result of HTTP requests. Categories: 1xx (Informational), 2xx (Success), 3xx (Redirection), 4xx (Client Error), 5xx (Server Error). Common codes include 200 OK, 201 Created, 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found, 500 Internal Server Error.
followUp: When would you use 204 vs 200 status code?
What's the difference between 401 and 403?

questions.question: What is JSON and how do you validate JSON structure in API responses?
questions.answer: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data-interchange format. It's human-readable and language-independent. Validation includes checking syntax (valid JSON), structure (expected fields), data types, and business rules. Tools like Postman, browser dev tools, or code can validate JSON.
followUp: What's the difference between JSON and XML?
How do you handle nested JSON objects?

questions.question: What are HTTP headers and why are they important in API testing?
questions.answer: HTTP headers provide additional information about the request or response. Important headers include Content-Type (data format), Authorization (authentication), Accept (preferred response format), User-Agent (client info), and custom headers. They control API behavior and security.
questions.code:
// Common request headers
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...
Accept: application/json
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64)
X-API-Key: your-api-key-here

// Common response headers
Content-Type: application/json
Content-Length: 1024
Cache-Control: max-age=3600
Location: /api/users/123 (for 201 Created)
Set-Cookie: sessionId=abc123; HttpOnly

// Example API request with headers
POST /api/users HTTP/1.1
Host: api.example.com
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer token123
Accept: application/json

{
  "name": "John Doe",
  "email": "john@example.com"
}

// Response with headers
HTTP/1.1 201 Created
Content-Type: application/json
Location: /api/users/123

questions.question: How do you test an API using Postman? Explain the basic steps
questions.answer: Postman is a popular API testing tool. Basic steps: 1) Enter API URL, 2) Select HTTP method, 3) Add headers if needed, 4) Add request body (for POST/PUT), 5) Send request, 6) Verify response status, headers, and body. Can save requests, create collections, and write tests.
companies: All companies requiring manual API testing
followUp: How do you create API test collections in Postman?
How to use environment variables in Postman?

questions.question: What is the difference between SOAP and REST APIs?
questions.answer: SOAP is a protocol with strict standards, uses XML, has built-in error handling, and supports complex operations. REST is an architectural style, uses multiple formats (JSON/XML), lightweight, stateless, and uses standard HTTP methods. REST is simpler and more popular for web APIs.
questions.code:
// REST API Example
// Simple and lightweight
GET /api/users/123
Accept: application/json

Response:
{
  "id": 123,
  "name": "John Doe",
  "email": "john@example.com"
}

// SOAP API Example
// Complex XML structure
POST /soap-endpoint
Content-Type: text/xml; charset=utf-8
SOAPAction: "GetUser"

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
  <soap:Body>
    <GetUser xmlns="http://tempuri.org/">
      <userId>123</userId>
    </GetUser>
  </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>

// SOAP Response
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
  <soap:Body>
    <GetUserResponse xmlns="http://tempuri.org/">
      <User>
        <Id>123</Id>
        <Name>John Doe</Name>
        <Email>john@example.com</Email>
      </User>
    </GetUserResponse>
  </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>
followUp: When would you choose SOAP over REST?
What are the security features in SOAP vs REST?

questions.question: How do you handle API authentication? Explain basic authentication methods
questions.answer: API authentication verifies user identity. Common methods: 1) API Keys (simple token), 2) Basic Auth (username:password Base64 encoded), 3) Bearer Token (JWT), 4) OAuth (secure delegation). Each has different security levels and use cases.
followUp: What is JWT and how does it work?
How do you test expired tokens?

questions.question: What is API documentation and how do you test APIs using documentation?
questions.answer: API documentation describes how to use an API, including endpoints, request/response formats, authentication, examples, and error codes. Tools like Swagger/OpenAPI provide interactive documentation. Good documentation helps testers understand expected behavior and write effective tests.
followUp: How do you test undocumented API features?
What makes good API documentation?

questions.question: How do you test query parameters and path parameters in APIs?
questions.answer: Path parameters are part of the URL path (e.g., /users/{id}) and identify specific resources. Query parameters follow '?' in URL (e.g., /users?page=1&size=10) and filter/modify requests. Test both for valid values, invalid values, missing parameters, and boundary conditions.
followUp: How do you handle special characters in query parameters?
What's the difference between query and form parameters?

questions.question: What is request body and how do you test different content types?
questions.answer: Request body contains data sent to the server (usually with POST/PUT/PATCH). Common content types: application/json (JSON data), application/x-www-form-urlencoded (form data), multipart/form-data (file uploads), text/plain, application/xml. Content-Type header specifies the format.
followUp: What happens if Content-Type doesn't match actual data?
How do you test large file uploads?

questions.question: How do you test API error handling and negative scenarios?
questions.answer: Negative testing ensures APIs handle errors gracefully. Test scenarios: invalid inputs, missing parameters, unauthorized access, server errors, timeouts, invalid URLs. Verify proper status codes, error messages, and response structure. Good APIs return consistent error formats with helpful messages.
companies: All companies focusing on API quality
followUp: How do you test API rate limiting?
What are common security vulnerabilities in APIs?

questions.question: What is API testing and why is it important?
questions.answer: API testing validates Application Programming Interfaces by testing data exchange between different software systems. It focuses on business logic, data exchange, functionality, and security. Important because: ensures system integration, faster than UI testing, early bug detection, supports automation, and validates backend functionality independently.
followUp: What's the difference between API testing and unit testing?
How does API testing fit in the test pyramid?

questions.question: How do you validate API response format and structure?
questions.answer: Response validation ensures API returns data in expected format and structure. Validate: status code, headers, response time, JSON structure, data types, required fields, field values, and business rules. Use tools like Postman tests, JSON schema validation, or automation frameworks.
followUp: How do you handle dynamic response data?
What is JSON schema validation?

questions.question: What tools are commonly used for API testing?
questions.answer: Popular API testing tools include: Manual testing - Postman, Insomnia, Swagger UI. Automation - REST Assured (Java), Requests (Python), Newman (Postman CLI), Karate, SoapUI. Performance - JMeter, LoadRunner. Each tool has different strengths for various testing needs.
followUp: How do you choose between different API testing tools?
What are the pros and cons of Postman vs REST Assured?

questions.question: How do you perform API load testing and performance testing?
questions.answer: API load testing validates system behavior under expected load conditions. Performance testing measures response times, throughput, resource utilization. Use tools like JMeter, LoadRunner, or REST Assured with threading. Test concurrent users, data volume, sustained load, spike testing.
followUp: What is the difference between load, stress, and spike testing?
How do you identify performance bottlenecks in APIs?

questions.question: How do you test GraphQL APIs? What are the key differences from REST testing?
questions.answer: GraphQL testing focuses on single endpoint with different queries/mutations. Test query structure, field selection, nested queries, variables, fragments, subscriptions. Key differences: single URL, POST requests, query validation, schema introspection, resolver testing.
followUp: How do you handle GraphQL subscriptions testing?
What are GraphQL fragments and how to test them?

questions.question: How do you implement API security testing? What vulnerabilities should you test for?
questions.answer: API security testing validates authentication, authorization, input validation, data protection. Test for OWASP API Top 10: broken authentication, excessive data exposure, injection attacks, broken authorization, security misconfiguration, insufficient logging.
followUp: How do you test for CSRF attacks in APIs?
What is JWT security testing?

questions.question: How do you test microservices APIs and handle service dependencies?
questions.answer: Microservices testing requires contract testing, service virtualization, chaos engineering, distributed tracing. Handle dependencies with mocking, stubs, test doubles. Implement consumer-driven contracts, API gateways testing, service mesh validation.
followUp: How do you implement chaos engineering for APIs?
What is the testing pyramid in microservices?

questions.question: How do you implement API monitoring and observability in testing?
questions.answer: API monitoring includes health checks, metrics collection, distributed tracing, log aggregation. Implement synthetic monitoring, SLA validation, alerting. Use tools like Prometheus, Grafana, ELK stack, Jaeger. Test monitoring systems and alert thresholds.
followUp: How do you test alert fatigue scenarios?
What are golden signals in API monitoring?

questions.question: What is REST API and how is it different from SOAP?
questions.answer: REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for web services using HTTP methods. SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) is a protocol with XML messaging. REST is simpler, lighter, uses JSON/XML. SOAP is more structured with built-in error handling and security.
followUp: What are the advantages of REST over SOAP?
When would you use SOAP instead of REST?

questions.question: What are HTTP status codes? Explain the main categories.
questions.answer: HTTP status codes indicate the result of HTTP requests. Categories: 1xx (Informational), 2xx (Success), 3xx (Redirection), 4xx (Client Error), 5xx (Server Error). Common codes: 200 OK, 201 Created, 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 404 Not Found, 500 Internal Server Error.
questions.code:
// Common HTTP Status Codes with examples

// 2xx Success
200 OK - Request successful
201 Created - Resource created successfully
204 No Content - Request successful, no content returned

// 3xx Redirection
301 Moved Permanently - Resource moved to new URL
302 Found - Temporary redirect

// 4xx Client Error
400 Bad Request - Invalid request syntax
401 Unauthorized - Authentication required
403 Forbidden - Access denied
404 Not Found - Resource not found
422 Unprocessable Entity - Request understood but validation failed

// 5xx Server Error
500 Internal Server Error - Server encountered an error
502 Bad Gateway - Invalid response from upstream server
503 Service Unavailable - Server temporarily unavailable

// Testing status codes in REST Assured
Response response = given()
    .when()
    .get("/api/users/123")
    .then()
    .statusCode(200)  // Assert status code
    .extract().response();

// Test different scenarios
given()
    .when()
    .get("/api/users/999")  // Non-existent user
    .then()
    .statusCode(404);  // Should return Not Found
followUp: What's the difference between 401 and 403?
When would you use 202 Accepted?

questions.question: What are HTTP methods? Explain GET, POST, PUT, DELETE with examples.
questions.answer: HTTP methods define actions to be performed. GET: retrieve data (safe, idempotent), POST: create/submit data (not idempotent), PUT: update/replace resource (idempotent), DELETE: remove resource (idempotent), PATCH: partial update.
followUp: What's the difference between PUT and PATCH?
Which HTTP methods are idempotent?

questions.question: What is JSON? How do you read and validate JSON in API testing?
questions.answer: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data interchange format. It's human-readable, language-independent, and uses key-value pairs. In API testing, validate JSON structure, data types, required fields, and values using tools like Postman or REST Assured.
followUp: What's the difference between JSON and XML?
How do you handle invalid JSON responses?

questions.question: How do you send different types of data in API requests (JSON, form data, files)?
questions.answer: API requests can send JSON (application/json), form data (application/x-www-form-urlencoded), multipart form data (multipart/form-data for files), XML, or plain text. Content-Type header specifies the data format being sent.
questions.code: \"name\": \"John Doe\",
\"email\": \"john@example.com\",
companies: All companies with file upload functionality
