questions.question: What is TestNG and what are its advantages over JUnit?
questions.answer: TestNG is a testing framework inspired by JUnit and NUnit. Advantages: supports data-driven testing, parallel execution, test dependencies, grouping, flexible test configuration with annotations, better reporting, and supports both unit and integration testing.

automationCompanies.note: TestNG is standard for enterprise test automation

followUp: What is the difference between @BeforeMethod and @BeforeTest?
How do you handle test failures in TestNG?

questions.question: Explain TestNG annotations and their execution order
questions.answer: TestNG annotations control test execution flow. Order: @BeforeSuite → @BeforeTest → @BeforeClass → @BeforeMethod → @Test → @AfterMethod → @AfterClass → @AfterTest → @AfterSuite. Each annotation serves specific setup/teardown purposes at different levels.
followUp: What happens if @BeforeClass method fails?
Can you have multiple @BeforeMethod annotations?

questions.question: How do you implement data-driven testing using DataProvider in TestNG?
questions.answer: DataProvider annotation supplies test data to test methods. It returns Object[][] array where each row represents one test iteration. Enables same test to run with different datasets, supporting external data sources like Excel, CSV, or databases.
followUp: How do you read data from Excel for DataProvider?", "What is the difference between DataProvider and Factory?

questions.question: How do you handle test dependencies in TestNG using dependsOnMethods?
questions.answer: dependsOnMethods ensures tests run in specific order. If prerequisite test fails, dependent tests are skipped. Use for scenarios where tests have logical dependencies like login → access dashboard → perform actions. Avoid overuse to maintain test independence.
followUp: What happens when a dependent test method fails?", "How do you handle circular dependencies?

questions.question: How do you organize tests using TestNG groups and run specific test groups?
questions.answer: Groups organize tests into logical categories (smoke, regression, sanity). Use @Test(groups = "groupname") to assign tests. Run specific groups via testng.xml or command line. Supports group inclusion/exclusion and group dependencies for flexible test execution.
followUp: How do you create custom group annotations?
What are meta-groups in TestNG?

questions.question: How do you configure parallel execution in TestNG?
questions.answer: TestNG supports parallel execution at method, class, and test level. Configure via @Test(threadPoolSize), suite XML parallel attribute, or annotations. Use thread-safe implementations and avoid shared mutable state. DataProvider can also run in parallel.
followUp: How do you handle shared resources in parallel execution?
What are the challenges with parallel testing?

questions.question: How do you create and configure TestNG XML suite files?
questions.answer: TestNG XML files define test execution configuration including suites, tests, classes, methods, parameters, and groups. XML provides fine-grained control over test execution order, parallel settings, and test selection. Essential for CI/CD integration.
questions.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<suite name="CompleteSuite" verbose="2" parallel="tests" thread-count="2">
    
    <!-- Suite level parameters -->
    <parameter name="browser" value="chrome" />
    <parameter name="environment" value="staging" />
    
    <!-- Test 1: Smoke Tests -->
    <test name="SmokeTest" preserve-order="true">
        <parameter name="testType" value="smoke" />
        
        <!-- Include/Exclude groups -->
        <groups>
            <run>
                <include name="smoke" />
                <exclude name="slow" />
            </run>
        </groups>
        
        <classes>
            <class name="tests.LoginTest">
                <methods>
                    <include name="testValidLogin" />
                    <exclude name="testInvalidLogin" />
                </methods>
            </class>
            <class name="tests.HomePageTest" />
        </classes>
    </test>
    
    <!-- Test 2: Regression Tests -->
    <test name="RegressionTest">
        <parameter name="testType" value="regression" />
        
        <groups>
            <run>
                <include name="regression" />
            </run>
        </groups>
        
        <packages>
            <package name="tests.regression.*" />
        </packages>
    </test>
    
    <!-- Listeners -->
    <listeners>
        <listener class-name="listeners.ScreenshotListener" />
        <listener class-name="listeners.ExtentReportListener" />
    </listeners>
    
</suite>
followUp: How do you pass runtime parameters to TestNG XML?
What is the difference between suite and test level parameters?

questions.question: How do you implement custom TestNG listeners for reporting and logging?
questions.answer: TestNG listeners hook into test execution lifecycle events. Common listeners: ITestListener (test start/finish), ISuiteListener (suite level), IReporter (custom reports). Implement interfaces to capture screenshots, log results, generate reports, send notifications.
followUp: How do you create custom reports using IReporter?
What's the difference between TestNG and JUnit listeners?

questions.question: How do you implement test retry mechanism and soft assertions in TestNG?
questions.answer: Test retry mechanism re-runs failed tests automatically using IRetryAnalyzer interface. Soft assertions continue test execution after assertion failure, collecting all failures. Both improve test stability and provide better failure reporting in complex test scenarios.
followUp: When should you use soft assertions vs hard assertions?
How do you implement conditional retry based on failure type?

questions.question: How do you integrate TestNG with Maven and Gradle build tools?
questions.answer: TestNG integrates with Maven via Surefire plugin and with Gradle via test task. Build tools manage dependencies, execute tests, generate reports, and integrate with CI/CD. Configuration includes test suite selection, parallel execution, and report generation.
questions.code:
<!-- Maven pom.xml configuration -->
<properties>
    <maven.compiler.source>11</maven.compiler.source>
    <maven.compiler.target>11</maven.compiler.target>
    <testng.version>7.4.0</testng.version>
</properties>

<dependencies>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.testng</groupId>
        <artifactId>testng</artifactId>
        <version>${testng.version}</version>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
</dependencies>

<build>
    <plugins>
        <plugin>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-surefire-plugin</artifactId>
            <version>3.0.0-M5</version>
            <configuration>
                <!-- Run specific TestNG suite -->
                <suiteXmlFiles>
                    <suiteXmlFile>src/test/resources/testng.xml</suiteXmlFile>
                </suiteXmlFiles>
                
                <!-- Parallel execution -->
                <parallel>methods</parallel>
                <threadCount>3</threadCount>
                
                <!-- Include/exclude tests -->
                <groups>smoke,regression</groups>
                <excludedGroups>slow</excludedGroups>
                
                <!-- System properties -->
                <systemPropertyVariables>
                    <browser>chrome</browser>
                    <environment>staging</environment>
                </systemPropertyVariables>
            </configuration>
        </plugin>
    </plugins>
</build>

// Gradle build.gradle configuration
dependencies {
    testImplementation 'org.testng:testng:7.4.0'
    testImplementation 'org.seleniumhq.selenium:selenium-java:4.1.0'
}

test {
    useTestNG() {
        // Use TestNG XML suite
        suites 'src/test/resources/testng.xml'
        
        // Include/exclude groups
        includeGroups 'smoke', 'regression'
        excludeGroups 'slow'
        
        // Parallel execution
        parallel 'methods'
        threadCount 3
        
        // Test output
        testLogging {
            events 'passed', 'skipped', 'failed'
            showStandardStreams = true
        }
    }
    
    // System properties
    systemProperty 'browser', System.getProperty('browser', 'chrome')
    systemProperty 'environment', System.getProperty('environment', 'staging')
}

// Custom test task for specific groups
task smokeTest(type: Test) {
    useTestNG {
        includeGroups 'smoke'
    }
}

task regressionTest(type: Test) {
    useTestNG {
        includeGroups 'regression'
    }
}

// Maven commands
// mvn test
// mvn test -Dgroups=smoke
// mvn test -Dbrowser=firefox
// mvn test -DsuiteXmlFile=smoke-suite.xml

// Gradle commands
// ./gradlew test
// ./gradlew smokeTest
// ./gradlew test -Dbrowser=firefox
followUp: How do you run tests in different environments using profiles?
How do you generate custom reports with build tools?

questions.question: What is Page Object Model (POM) and why is it important in automation frameworks?
questions.answer: Page Object Model (POM) is a design pattern that creates an object repository for web UI elements. Each web page is represented as a class with elements as variables and actions as methods. It improves maintainability, reusability, and reduces code duplication. Changes in UI require updates only in corresponding page classes.
followUp: What's the difference between POM and Page Factory?
How do you handle dynamic elements in POM?

questions.question: What are the different types of automation frameworks and their advantages?
questions.answer: 1) Linear Framework: Simple record-playback, no reusability. 2) Modular Framework: Breaks application into modules/functions, better maintainability. 3) Data-Driven Framework: Separates test data from scripts, uses external data sources. 4) Keyword-Driven Framework: Actions defined as keywords, non-technical users can create tests. 5) Hybrid Framework: Combines multiple approaches for maximum benefits.
followUp: When would you choose keyword-driven over data-driven?
How do you implement a hybrid framework?

questions.question: How do you implement data-driven testing in your automation framework?
questions.answer: Data-driven testing separates test logic from test data using external sources like Excel, CSV, JSON, or databases. Implement using TestNG DataProvider, parameterized tests, or external data readers. Benefits include running same test with multiple data sets, easier test maintenance, and better test coverage.
followUp: How do you handle large datasets in data-driven tests?
What's the best way to manage test data dependencies?

questions.question: How do you implement reporting in automation frameworks (ExtentReports, Allure)?
questions.answer: Implement custom reporting using ExtentReports or Allure for detailed test execution reports. ExtentReports provides rich HTML reports with screenshots, logs, and test details. Allure offers advanced features like test categorization, history trends, and attachments. Both integrate with TestNG listeners for automatic report generation.
followUp: How do you integrate reports with CI/CD pipelines?
What's the difference between ExtentReports and Allure?

questions.question: How do you design a scalable automation framework architecture?
questions.answer: Scalable framework design follows layered architecture with separation of concerns: 1) Driver Management Layer (WebDriver factory, browser configuration). 2) Page Object Layer (POM classes, element repositories). 3) Test Data Layer (external data sources, data providers). 4) Utility Layer (common functions, helpers). 5) Test Layer (test classes, test suites). 6) Reporting Layer (test reports, logging). 7) Configuration Layer (environment settings, properties).
followUp: How do you handle environment-specific configurations?
What design patterns do you use in automation frameworks?

questions.question: What is database testing and what are the different types?
questions.answer: Database testing validates database operations, data validity, performance, triggers, and procedures. Types: Structural Testing (schema, tables, columns), Functional Testing (CRUD operations), Non-functional Testing (performance, load), Data Validity Testing (accuracy, integrity), Trigger Testing (automated actions).
followUp: What is the difference between database testing and data testing?
How do you test database performance?

questions.question: Explain SQL JOIN types with practical examples
questions.answer: SQL JOINs combine data from multiple tables. INNER JOIN returns matching records. LEFT JOIN returns all left table records + matching right. RIGHT JOIN returns all right table records + matching left. FULL OUTER JOIN returns all records when match in either table. CROSS JOIN returns Cartesian product.
followUp: When would you use LEFT JOIN vs INNER JOIN?
What is the performance difference between JOINs?

questions.question: How do you validate data integrity and constraints in database testing?
questions.answer: Data integrity ensures accuracy and consistency. Test Primary Keys (uniqueness), Foreign Keys (referential integrity), NOT NULL constraints, CHECK constraints, UNIQUE constraints. Validate triggers, stored procedures, and business rules. Test cascade operations and constraint violations.
followUp: How do you test stored procedures?
What are ACID properties and how to test them?

questions.question: How do you perform database performance testing and identify bottlenecks?
questions.answer: Performance testing measures response time, throughput, resource utilization. Test query execution plans, index usage, concurrent access, deadlocks. Use EXPLAIN PLAN, monitor slow query logs, test with realistic data volumes. Identify bottlenecks: missing indexes, inefficient queries, locking issues, hardware constraints.
followUp: How do you test database connection pooling?
What tools do you use for database monitoring?

questions.question: What is SQL and what are the basic components of a SQL statement?
questions.answer: SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to communicate with databases. Basic components include: Keywords (SELECT, FROM, WHERE), Tables (data storage), Columns (fields), Rows (records), Operators (=, >, <), Functions (COUNT, SUM), and Clauses (WHERE, ORDER BY, GROUP BY).
questions.code:
-- Basic SQL statement structure
SELECT column1, column2    -- Columns to retrieve
FROM table_name           -- Table to query
WHERE condition           -- Filter criteria
ORDER BY column1;         -- Sort results

-- Example with sample data
-- Table: employees
-- | id | name    | salary | department |
-- | 1  | John    | 50000  | IT         |
-- | 2  | Jane    | 60000  | HR         |
-- | 3  | Bob     | 55000  | IT         |

-- Select all employees
SELECT * FROM employees;

-- Select specific columns
SELECT name, salary FROM employees;

-- Select with condition
SELECT name, salary 
FROM employees 
WHERE department = 'IT';

-- Select with sorting
SELECT name, salary 
FROM employees 
ORDER BY salary DESC;
followUp: What are the different types of SQL commands?
What is the difference between SQL and NoSQL?

questions.question: How do you insert data into a database table using SQL INSERT statement?
questions.answer: INSERT statement adds new records to a table. Syntax: INSERT INTO table_name (column1, column2, ...) VALUES (value1, value2, ...). Can insert single or multiple rows. Values must match column data types and constraints.
questions.code:
-- Table structure: users (id, name, email, age)

-- Insert single record with all columns
INSERT INTO users (id, name, email, age) 
VALUES (1, 'John Doe', 'john@example.com', 25);

-- Insert without specifying all columns (if some allow NULL or have defaults)
INSERT INTO users (name, email) 
VALUES ('Jane Smith', 'jane@example.com');

-- Insert multiple records at once
INSERT INTO users (name, email, age) VALUES 
    ('Alice Johnson', 'alice@example.com', 30),
    ('Bob Wilson', 'bob@example.com', 28),
    ('Carol Brown', 'carol@example.com', 35);

-- Insert data from another table
INSERT INTO users_backup (name, email, age)
SELECT name, email, age 
FROM users 
WHERE age > 25;

-- Insert with specific column order
INSERT INTO users (email, name, age) 
VALUES ('mike@example.com', 'Mike Davis', 32);

-- Common errors to test:
-- 1. Missing required columns
-- INSERT INTO users (name) VALUES ('Test');  -- May fail if email is required
-- 2. Data type mismatch
-- INSERT INTO users (name, email, age) VALUES ('Test', 'test@test.com', 'twenty');  -- age should be number
-- 3. Duplicate primary key
-- INSERT INTO users (id, name, email) VALUES (1, 'Duplicate', 'dup@test.com');  -- May fail if id=1 exists
followUp: How do you handle auto-increment primary keys?
What happens when INSERT fails due to constraints?

questions.question: How do you retrieve data from a database using SQL SELECT statement?
questions.answer: SELECT statement retrieves data from tables. Basic syntax: SELECT columns FROM table WHERE condition. Can filter with WHERE, sort with ORDER BY, group with GROUP BY, and limit results. Use * to select all columns or specify column names.
questions.code:
-- Sample table: products (id, name, price, category, stock)
-- | 1 | Laptop    | 999.99 | Electronics | 10 |
-- | 2 | Desk      | 299.50 | Furniture   | 25 |
-- | 3 | Mouse     | 25.99  | Electronics | 50 |
-- | 4 | Chair     | 199.99 | Furniture   | 15 |

-- Select all columns and all rows
SELECT * FROM products;

-- Select specific columns
SELECT name, price FROM products;

-- Select with WHERE condition
SELECT name, price 
FROM products 
WHERE category = 'Electronics';

-- Select with multiple conditions
SELECT name, price, stock
FROM products 
WHERE category = 'Electronics' AND price < 500;

-- Select with OR condition
SELECT name, price
FROM products 
WHERE category = 'Electronics' OR category = 'Furniture';

-- Select with sorting
SELECT name, price 
FROM products 
ORDER BY price DESC;  -- Highest price first

-- Select with LIMIT (MySQL/PostgreSQL)
SELECT name, price 
FROM products 
ORDER BY price DESC 
LIMIT 2;  -- Top 2 most expensive

-- Select with LIKE for pattern matching
SELECT name, price 
FROM products 
WHERE name LIKE '%a%';  -- Names containing 'a'

-- Select with ranges
SELECT name, price 
FROM products 
WHERE price BETWEEN 100 AND 500;

-- Select with NULL checks
SELECT name, price 
FROM products 
WHERE description IS NOT NULL;
followUp: What is the difference between WHERE and HAVING?
How do you use wildcards in SQL?

questions.question: How do you update existing data in a database using SQL UPDATE statement?
questions.answer: UPDATE statement modifies existing records. Syntax: UPDATE table_name SET column1 = value1, column2 = value2 WHERE condition. Always use WHERE clause to avoid updating all rows. Can update single or multiple columns and rows.
questions.code:
-- Sample table: employees (id, name, salary, department, email)
-- | 1 | John Doe  | 50000 | IT | john@company.com    |
-- | 2 | Jane Smith| 60000 | HR | jane@company.com    |
-- | 3 | Bob Wilson| 55000 | IT | bob@company.com     |

-- Update single column for one record
UPDATE employees 
SET salary = 55000 
WHERE id = 1;

-- Update multiple columns for one record
UPDATE employees 
SET salary = 65000, department = 'Management' 
WHERE id = 2;

-- Update multiple records with same condition
UPDATE employees 
SET salary = salary * 1.10 
WHERE department = 'IT';  -- 10% raise for IT department

-- Update with calculations
UPDATE employees 
SET salary = salary + 5000 
WHERE salary < 60000;

-- Update using subquery
UPDATE employees 
SET department = 'Senior IT' 
WHERE id IN (SELECT id FROM employees WHERE department = 'IT' AND salary > 55000);

-- Update with string functions
UPDATE employees 
SET email = LOWER(email) 
WHERE email IS NOT NULL;

-- Update with conditions
UPDATE employees 
SET salary = CASE 
    WHEN department = 'IT' THEN salary * 1.15
    WHEN department = 'HR' THEN salary * 1.10
    ELSE salary * 1.05
END;

-- IMPORTANT: Always use WHERE clause!
-- This updates ALL records (dangerous!):
-- UPDATE employees SET salary = 50000;  -- NO WHERE CLAUSE!

-- Safe practice: Check with SELECT first
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE id = 1;  -- Verify record exists
UPDATE employees SET salary = 60000 WHERE id = 1;  -- Then update
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE id = 1;  -- Verify update
followUp: What happens if UPDATE affects multiple rows?
How do you update with JOIN conditions?

questions.question: How do you delete data from a database using SQL DELETE statement?
questions.answer: DELETE statement removes records from a table. Syntax: DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition. Always use WHERE clause to avoid deleting all records. DELETE removes entire rows, unlike UPDATE which modifies specific columns.
questions.code:
-- Sample table: customers (id, name, email, status, last_login)
-- | 1 | John    | john@email.com    | active   | 2023-12-01 |
-- | 2 | Jane    | jane@email.com    | inactive | 2023-01-15 |
-- | 3 | Bob     | bob@email.com     | active   | 2023-11-30 |
-- | 4 | Alice   | alice@email.com   | inactive | 2022-06-01 |

-- Delete single record by ID
DELETE FROM customers 
WHERE id = 2;

-- Delete records with specific condition
DELETE FROM customers 
WHERE status = 'inactive';

-- Delete records with date condition
DELETE FROM customers 
WHERE last_login < '2023-01-01';

-- Delete with multiple conditions
DELETE FROM customers 
WHERE status = 'inactive' AND last_login < '2023-06-01';

-- Delete using subquery
DELETE FROM customers 
WHERE id IN (
    SELECT id FROM customers 
    WHERE status = 'inactive' AND last_login < '2022-12-31'
);

-- Delete with JOIN (MySQL syntax)
DELETE c FROM customers c 
JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id 
WHERE o.total_amount < 10;

-- DANGEROUS: Delete all records (no WHERE clause)
-- DELETE FROM customers;  -- This deletes ALL records!

-- Safe practices:
-- 1. Always test with SELECT first
SELECT * FROM customers WHERE status = 'inactive';  -- Check what will be deleted
DELETE FROM customers WHERE status = 'inactive';    -- Then delete

-- 2. Use transactions for safety
BEGIN TRANSACTION;
DELETE FROM customers WHERE id = 5;
-- Check if correct record was deleted
SELECT * FROM customers WHERE id = 5;  -- Should return no results
COMMIT;  -- or ROLLBACK if something went wrong

-- 3. Consider soft delete instead of hard delete
UPDATE customers SET deleted = 1, deleted_at = NOW() WHERE id = 5;
-- Instead of: DELETE FROM customers WHERE id = 5;
followUp: What is the difference between DELETE and TRUNCATE?
How do you implement soft deletes?

questions.question: What are the basic SQL data types and when do you use each?
questions.answer: Common SQL data types include: INTEGER/INT (whole numbers), VARCHAR (variable-length text), CHAR (fixed-length text), DECIMAL/NUMERIC (precise numbers), DATE/DATETIME/TIMESTAMP (dates and times), BOOLEAN (true/false), TEXT (large text), BLOB (binary data). Choice depends on data size and requirements.
questions.code:
-- Creating table with different data types
CREATE TABLE products (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,           -- Whole numbers, primary key
    name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,       -- Variable text up to 255 chars
    code CHAR(10) UNIQUE,            -- Fixed 10-character code
    price DECIMAL(10, 2),            -- Price with 2 decimal places
    description TEXT,                 -- Large text content
    is_active BOOLEAN DEFAULT true,   -- True/false flag
    created_date DATE,               -- Date only (YYYY-MM-DD)
    last_updated DATETIME,           -- Date and time
    image_data BLOB                  -- Binary data for images
);

-- Inserting data with different types
INSERT INTO products (
    id, name, code, price, description, 
    is_active, created_date, last_updated
) VALUES (
    1,                               -- INTEGER
    'Wireless Headphones',           -- VARCHAR
    'WH001',                         -- CHAR
    99.99,                           -- DECIMAL
    'High-quality wireless headphones with noise cancellation', -- TEXT
    true,                            -- BOOLEAN
    '2023-12-01',                    -- DATE
    '2023-12-01 10:30:00'           -- DATETIME
);

-- Data type constraints and validation
INSERT INTO products (id, name, code, price) VALUES 
    (2, 'Smartphone', 'SM002', 599.50),  -- Valid decimal
    (3, 'Tablet', 'TB003', 299);         -- Integer converted to decimal

-- Common data type errors to test:
-- 1. String too long for VARCHAR
-- INSERT INTO products (name) VALUES ('Very long product name that exceeds the 255 character limit...');

-- 2. Invalid date format
-- INSERT INTO products (created_date) VALUES ('2023-13-01');  -- Invalid month

-- 3. Wrong data type
-- INSERT INTO products (price) VALUES ('not a number');  -- String in numeric field

-- Selecting and formatting different data types
SELECT 
    id,
    name,
    UPPER(code) as formatted_code,     -- String function
    ROUND(price, 0) as rounded_price,  -- Numeric function
    DATE_FORMAT(created_date, '%Y-%m-%d') as formatted_date,  -- Date formatting
    CASE WHEN is_active THEN 'Yes' ELSE 'No' END as status   -- Boolean formatting
FROM products;
followUp: How do you choose between VARCHAR and CHAR?
What is the difference between DATE and DATETIME?

questions.question: How do you use WHERE clause to filter data in SQL queries?
questions.answer: WHERE clause filters rows based on specified conditions. Supports comparison operators (=, !=, >, <, >=, <=), logical operators (AND, OR, NOT), pattern matching (LIKE), range checking (BETWEEN), and null checking (IS NULL). Conditions are evaluated before SELECT.
followUp: What is the difference between = and LIKE?
How do you use wildcards with LIKE?

questions.question: How do you sort data using ORDER BY clause in SQL?
questions.answer: ORDER BY clause sorts query results. Syntax: ORDER BY column1 [ASC|DESC], column2 [ASC|DESC]. ASC (ascending) is default, DESC for descending. Can sort by multiple columns, expressions, or column positions. Sort order affects query performance and result presentation.
questions.code:
-- Sample table: students (id, name, age, grade, subject, score)
-- | 1 | Alice  | 20 | A | Math    | 95 |
-- | 2 | Bob    | 22 | B | Math    | 85 |
-- | 3 | Charlie| 19 | A | Science | 92 |
-- | 4 | Diana  | 21 | B | Science | 88 |
-- | 5 | Eve    | 20 | A | Math    | 98 |

-- Sort by single column (ascending - default)
SELECT name, age, score FROM students ORDER BY score;
-- Result: Bob(85), Diana(88), Charlie(92), Alice(95), Eve(98)

-- Sort by single column (descending)
SELECT name, age, score FROM students ORDER BY score DESC;
-- Result: Eve(98), Alice(95), Charlie(92), Diana(88), Bob(85)

-- Sort by multiple columns
SELECT name, subject, score 
FROM students 
ORDER BY subject ASC, score DESC;
-- First by subject (alphabetical), then by score (highest first)

-- Sort by column position (not recommended but valid)
SELECT name, age, score FROM students ORDER BY 3 DESC;
-- Sorts by 3rd column (score) in descending order

-- Sort with WHERE condition
SELECT name, score 
FROM students 
WHERE subject = 'Math' 
ORDER BY score DESC;

-- Sort by expression/calculation
SELECT name, age, score, (score * 0.8 + age * 0.2) as weighted_score
FROM students 
ORDER BY weighted_score DESC;

-- Sort by string functions
SELECT name, grade 
FROM students 
ORDER BY LENGTH(name), name;  -- Sort by name length, then alphabetically

-- Sort with NULL values (behavior varies by database)
SELECT name, email 
FROM students 
ORDER BY email;  -- NULLs typically appear first or last

-- MySQL: Control NULL ordering
SELECT name, email 
FROM students 
ORDER BY email IS NULL, email;  -- NULLs last

-- Sort by CASE expression
SELECT name, grade, score
FROM students 
ORDER BY 
    CASE grade 
        WHEN 'A' THEN 1 
        WHEN 'B' THEN 2 
        WHEN 'C' THEN 3 
        ELSE 4 
    END,
    score DESC;

-- Limit sorted results (MySQL/PostgreSQL)
SELECT name, score 
FROM students 
ORDER BY score DESC 
LIMIT 3;  -- Top 3 highest scores

-- Performance tip: ORDER BY with index
-- CREATE INDEX idx_students_score ON students(score);
-- SELECT * FROM students ORDER BY score;  -- Will use index
followUp: How does ORDER BY affect query performance?
What happens when you ORDER BY multiple columns?

questions.question: What are SQL aggregate functions and how do you use them?
questions.answer: Aggregate functions perform calculations on multiple rows and return single values. Common functions: COUNT (count rows), SUM (total), AVG (average), MIN/MAX (minimum/maximum). Often used with GROUP BY to calculate values for each group. NULL values are typically ignored.
questions.code:
-- Sample table: sales (id, product, quantity, price, sale_date, region)
-- | 1 | Laptop | 2  | 999.99 | 2023-01-15 | North |
-- | 2 | Mouse  | 10 | 25.99  | 2023-01-16 | South |
-- | 3 | Laptop | 1  | 999.99 | 2023-01-17 | North |
-- | 4 | Keyboard| 5 | 79.99  | 2023-01-18 | East  |
-- | 5 | Mouse  | 8  | 25.99  | 2023-01-19 | West  |

-- COUNT: Number of records
SELECT COUNT(*) as total_sales FROM sales;
SELECT COUNT(product) as product_count FROM sales;
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT product) as unique_products FROM sales;

-- SUM: Total of numeric values
SELECT SUM(quantity) as total_quantity FROM sales;
SELECT SUM(quantity * price) as total_revenue FROM sales;

-- AVG: Average value
SELECT AVG(price) as average_price FROM sales;
SELECT AVG(quantity) as average_quantity FROM sales;

-- MIN and MAX: Minimum and maximum values
SELECT MIN(price) as cheapest_item FROM sales;
SELECT MAX(price) as most_expensive_item FROM sales;
SELECT MIN(sale_date) as first_sale, MAX(sale_date) as last_sale FROM sales;

-- Multiple aggregates in one query
SELECT 
    COUNT(*) as total_sales,
    SUM(quantity) as total_items_sold,
    AVG(price) as average_price,
    MIN(price) as min_price,
    MAX(price) as max_price,
    SUM(quantity * price) as total_revenue
FROM sales;

-- Aggregates with WHERE condition
SELECT COUNT(*) as laptop_sales, SUM(quantity) as laptops_sold
FROM sales 
WHERE product = 'Laptop';

-- GROUP BY with aggregates
SELECT 
    product,
    COUNT(*) as sales_count,
    SUM(quantity) as total_sold,
    AVG(price) as avg_price
FROM sales 
GROUP BY product;

-- GROUP BY with multiple columns
SELECT 
    product,
    region,
    COUNT(*) as sales_count,
    SUM(quantity * price) as revenue
FROM sales 
GROUP BY product, region
ORDER BY revenue DESC;

-- HAVING clause (filter groups after aggregation)
SELECT 
    product,
    COUNT(*) as sales_count,
    SUM(quantity) as total_sold
FROM sales 
GROUP BY product
HAVING COUNT(*) > 1;  -- Products with more than 1 sale

-- Complex aggregation with CASE
SELECT 
    COUNT(*) as total_sales,
    SUM(CASE WHEN price > 100 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) as expensive_items,
    SUM(CASE WHEN price <= 100 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) as affordable_items,
    AVG(CASE WHEN product = 'Laptop' THEN price END) as avg_laptop_price
FROM sales;
followUp: What is the difference between WHERE and HAVING?
How do you handle NULL values in aggregate functions?

questions.question: How do you create and modify database tables using DDL statements?
questions.answer: DDL (Data Definition Language) statements define database structure. CREATE TABLE creates tables with columns and constraints. ALTER TABLE modifies existing tables (add/drop columns, modify data types). DROP TABLE deletes tables. Constraints ensure data integrity (PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, NOT NULL, UNIQUE).
followUp: What are the different types of constraints in SQL?
How do you handle schema migrations in production?

questions.question: What is a primary key and why is it important in database tables?
questions.answer: Primary key is a unique identifier for each row in a table. It cannot be NULL or duplicate. Ensures data integrity, creates clustered index for faster access, used for relationships between tables. Every table should have a primary key for proper database design.
followUp: What is the difference between primary key and unique key?
Can a table have multiple primary keys?

questions.question: What is a foreign key and how do you create relationships between tables?
questions.answer: Foreign key is a column that references the primary key of another table, creating relationships between tables. Ensures referential integrity - prevents invalid data. Child table cannot have values that don't exist in parent table. Supports CASCADE operations for updates and deletes.
questions.code:
-- Parent table
CREATE TABLE departments (
    dept_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
    dept_name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    location VARCHAR(100)
);

-- Child table with foreign key
CREATE TABLE employees (
    emp_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    dept_id INT,
    salary DECIMAL(10, 2),
    FOREIGN KEY (dept_id) REFERENCES departments(dept_id)
);

-- Foreign key with CASCADE options
CREATE TABLE orders (
    order_id INT PRIMARY KEY,
    customer_id INT,
    order_date DATE,
    FOREIGN KEY (customer_id) REFERENCES customers(customer_id)
        ON DELETE CASCADE           -- Delete orders when customer is deleted
        ON UPDATE CASCADE           -- Update orders when customer ID changes
);

-- Insert data following foreign key rules
INSERT INTO departments VALUES (1, 'IT', 'Building A');
INSERT INTO departments VALUES (2, 'HR', 'Building B');

-- Valid inserts - dept_id exists in parent table
INSERT INTO employees VALUES (101, 'John Doe', 1, 50000);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES (102, 'Jane Smith', 2, 60000);

-- This will fail - dept_id = 99 doesn't exist in departments
-- INSERT INTO employees VALUES (103, 'Bob Wilson', 99, 55000);

-- Testing referential integrity
-- This will fail - cannot delete department with employees
-- DELETE FROM departments WHERE dept_id = 1;

-- View foreign key relationships
SHOW CREATE TABLE employees;  -- MySQL
-- Or use information_schema tables
SELECT 
    TABLE_NAME,
    COLUMN_NAME,
    REFERENCED_TABLE_NAME,
    REFERENCED_COLUMN_NAME
FROM information_schema.KEY_COLUMN_USAGE
WHERE REFERENCED_TABLE_SCHEMA = 'your_database'
AND TABLE_NAME = 'employees';
followUp: What are CASCADE operations in foreign keys?
What happens when you try to delete a parent record with child records?

questions.question: How do you test stored procedures and functions in database testing?
questions.answer: Stored procedure testing validates input parameters, output results, exception handling, and business logic. Test boundary values, null inputs, invalid data, performance under load. Verify return codes, out parameters, result sets. Mock external dependencies and test rollback scenarios.
followUp: How do you test stored procedures with cursors?
What are best practices for stored procedure testing?

questions.question: How do you test ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) in database transactions?
questions.answer: ACID testing ensures transaction reliability. Atomicity: test rollback on failure. Consistency: verify constraints maintained. Isolation: test concurrent transactions don't interfere. Durability: verify data persists after commit, even with system failures. Use transaction boundaries, deadlock simulation, concurrent access testing.
followUp: How do you test deadlock scenarios?
What are different transaction isolation levels?

questions.question: How do you test NoSQL databases? What are the key differences from SQL database testing?
questions.answer: NoSQL testing focuses on document structure, schema-less data, horizontal scaling, eventual consistency. Test data modeling, query performance, replication, sharding. Key differences: flexible schema, eventual consistency vs ACID, different query languages, horizontal scaling considerations.
followUp: How do you test MongoDB sharding?
What are the challenges with testing eventual consistency?

questions.question: How do you implement database migration testing and schema versioning?
questions.answer: Migration testing ensures schema changes are applied safely without data loss. Test forward migrations, rollbacks, data preservation, performance impact. Use version control for schemas, automated migration tools, staging environment validation. Test large dataset migrations, concurrent access during migration.
followUp: How do you handle zero-downtime migrations?
What are blue-green deployment strategies for databases?

questions.question: What is performance testing and what are its different types?
questions.answer: Performance testing evaluates system responsiveness, stability, and scalability under various load conditions. Types: Load Testing (expected load), Stress Testing (beyond normal capacity), Volume Testing (large amounts of data), Spike Testing (sudden load increases), Endurance Testing (extended periods), Scalability Testing (scaling up/down).
followUp: What are the key performance testing metrics?
How do you determine performance testing requirements?

questions.question: How do you set up and configure JMeter for API performance testing?
questions.answer: JMeter setup involves creating Test Plan with Thread Groups, HTTP Request samplers, timers, and listeners. Configure thread properties (users, ramp-up, duration), add assertions for validation, use CSV Data Set for parameterization, and implement realistic test scenarios with think time and proper correlation.
questions.code: API Performance Testing Plan false false baseURL https://api.example.com port 443 ${baseURL} ${port} https UTF-8 Content-Type application/json Authorization Bearer ${authToken} , UTF-8 testdata.csv true true shareMode.all false userId,userName,userEmail 100 300 1800 true continue false ${userId} = true id /api/users GET true false true 200 Assertion.response_code false 1 2000 1000 2000 false saveConfig true true true true true true true true false true true false false false false false false false false 0 results.jtl false // Command Line Execution // jmeter -n -t test-plan.jmx -l results.jtl -e -o report-folder // -n: non-GUI mode // -t: test plan file // -l: results file // -e: generate report dashboard // -o: output folder for reports
followUp: How do you implement correlation in JMeter?
What are JMeter best practices for large-scale testing?

questions.question: What are the key performance testing metrics and how do you analyze them?
questions.answer: Key metrics include Response Time (average, median, 90th/95th/99th percentiles), Throughput (requests/transactions per second), Error Rate (percentage of failed requests), Resource Utilization (CPU, Memory, Disk I/O), Concurrent Users, and Scalability metrics. Analysis involves identifying bottlenecks, performance degradation points, and capacity limits.
followUp: How do you establish performance baselines?
What tools do you use for real-time performance monitoring?

questions.question: How do you implement performance testing in CI/CD pipelines?
questions.answer: Integrate performance testing using automated gates with defined thresholds, shift-left approach with smoke performance tests in early stages, trend analysis across builds, and fail-fast mechanisms. Use tools like Jenkins, GitLab CI, or Azure DevOps with JMeter, k6, or Gatling. Implement performance budgets and SLA monitoring.
followUp: How do you handle performance test data management in pipelines?
What strategies do you use for environment provisioning in performance testing?

questions.question: How do you perform scalability testing and capacity planning?
questions.answer: Scalability testing evaluates system's ability to scale up (vertical) or out (horizontal) under increasing load. Involves load modeling, identifying breaking points, resource utilization analysis, and bottleneck identification. Capacity planning uses historical data, growth projections, and performance models to determine infrastructure requirements.
followUp: How do you model user behavior for realistic load testing?
What are the considerations for testing microservices scalability?

questions.question: What is mobile testing and how is it different from web testing? Explain native, hybrid, and web app testing approaches.
questions.answer: Mobile testing validates applications on mobile devices/platforms. Native apps are platform-specific (iOS/Android), hybrid apps combine web and native technologies, web apps run in mobile browsers. Key differences: device variety, OS fragmentation, touch interactions, performance constraints, network conditions, battery usage, and mobile-specific features like GPS, camera.
followUp: What are the challenges in mobile device fragmentation testing?
How do you test mobile app security and permissions?

questions.question: How do you set up Appium for Android and iOS testing? Explain the architecture and components.
questions.answer: Appium is an open-source tool for mobile automation using WebDriver protocol. Architecture: Appium Server receives commands, translates to platform-specific automation frameworks (UiAutomator2 for Android, XCUITest for iOS), executes on devices/simulators. Setup involves Appium server, platform SDKs, desired capabilities configuration, and device/emulator setup.
followUp: How do you handle Appium server scaling for parallel execution?
What are the common Appium setup issues and solutions?

questions.question: How do you handle different mobile locator strategies and element identification in Appium?
questions.answer: Mobile locators include platform-specific strategies: Android (UiSelector, UiScrollable, resource-id), iOS (NSPredicate, class chain, accessibility-id), and cross-platform (XPath, accessibility-id). Best practices: prefer accessibility-id over XPath, use platform-specific locators for performance, implement Page Object Model for maintainability.
followUp: How do you handle dynamic content and lazy loading in mobile apps?
What are the performance implications of different locator strategies?

questions.question: How do you implement mobile gestures and touch actions using Appium TouchAction?
questions.answer: TouchAction class handles mobile gestures: tap, long press, swipe, pinch, zoom, drag-drop. Uses PointOption for coordinates, WaitOptions for timing, and chaining for complex gestures. Important for testing mobile-specific interactions like scrolling, swiping between screens, pinch-to-zoom, and multi-touch scenarios.
followUp: How do you test gesture conflicts and edge cases?
What are the challenges in testing gestures across different screen sizes?

questions.question: How do you handle mobile-specific challenges like network conditions, device orientation, and app states?
questions.answer: Mobile testing requires handling network simulation (airplane mode, slow connections), device orientation changes, app background/foreground states, push notifications, device sensors, permissions, and battery optimization. Use Appium capabilities for network simulation, orientation management, and app state transitions for comprehensive mobile testing.
followUp: How do you test mobile app security and data encryption?
What strategies do you use for testing across different mobile OS versions?

questions.question: What is security testing and what are the OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities?
questions.answer: Security testing identifies vulnerabilities and security flaws in applications. OWASP Top 10 (2021): 1) Broken Access Control, 2) Cryptographic Failures, 3) Injection, 4) Insecure Design, 5) Security Misconfiguration, 6) Vulnerable Components, 7) Identification & Authentication Failures, 8) Software & Data Integrity Failures, 9) Security Logging & Monitoring Failures, 10) Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF).
followUp: How do you perform security testing in CI/CD pipelines?
What tools do you use for automated security testing?

questions.question: How do you test API security including authentication, authorization, and input validation?
questions.answer: API security testing covers authentication mechanisms (JWT, OAuth), authorization controls (RBAC, ABAC), input validation, rate limiting, and secure communications (HTTPS, TLS). Test for token manipulation, privilege escalation, parameter tampering, and API enumeration vulnerabilities.
followUp: How do you test OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect security?
What are common API security misconfigurations?

questions.question: How do you implement automated security testing in CI/CD pipelines using security tools?
questions.answer: Automated security testing in CI/CD involves SAST (Static Application Security Testing), DAST (Dynamic Application Security Testing), SCA (Software Composition Analysis), and infrastructure scanning. Tools like OWASP ZAP, SonarQube, Snyk, and Checkmarx integrate with pipelines to provide security gates and vulnerability reporting.
followUp: How do you handle false positives in automated security testing?
What are the challenges of implementing shift-left security?

questions.question: How do you test web application security including XSS, CSRF, and session management vulnerabilities?
questions.answer: Web application security testing requires comprehensive testing of client-side and server-side vulnerabilities. XSS testing includes reflected, stored, and DOM-based variants. CSRF testing validates token implementation and SameSite attributes. Session management testing covers session fixation, hijacking, and secure cookie configurations.
followUp: How do you test for SQL injection in complex applications?
What are the latest web security threats and testing approaches?

questions.question: How do you test infrastructure security including network, container, and cloud security configurations?
questions.answer: Infrastructure security testing encompasses network security (ports, protocols, firewalls), container security (image vulnerabilities, runtime security, orchestration), and cloud security (IAM, encryption, compliance). Tools like Nmap, Docker Bench, AWS Config, and infrastructure-as-code scanners validate security configurations.
followUp: How do you implement security scanning in infrastructure as code?
What are the key security considerations for microservices architecture?

questions.question: How do you integrate automated testing into a Jenkins CI/CD pipeline?
questions.answer: Jenkins CI/CD integration involves creating pipeline stages for different test types: unit tests, integration tests, API tests, and UI tests. Use Jenkinsfile for pipeline as code, parallel execution for faster feedback, test result publishing, and failure notifications. Configure triggers for commits, scheduled runs, and manual deployments.
followUp: How do you handle test failures in pipelines?
What are best practices for pipeline optimization?

questions.question: How do you containerize Selenium tests using Docker and run them in Kubernetes?
questions.answer: Docker containerization involves creating lightweight images with test dependencies, using Selenium Grid for distributed execution, and Kubernetes for orchestration and scaling. This approach provides consistent execution environments, easy scaling, and resource optimization across different environments.
questions.code:
# Dockerfile for Selenium Tests
FROM openjdk:11-jre-slim

# Install dependencies
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y \
    wget \
    gnupg \
    unzip \
    curl \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Install Chrome
RUN wget -q -O - https://dl-ssl.google.com/linux/linux_signing_key.pub | apt-key add - \
    && echo "deb [arch=amd64] http://dl.google.com/linux/chrome/deb/ stable main" >> /etc/apt/sources.list.d/google-chrome.list \
    && apt-get update \
    && apt-get install -y google-chrome-stable

# Install ChromeDriver
RUN CHROME_DRIVER_VERSION=`curl -sS chromedriver.storage.googleapis.com/LATEST_RELEASE` \
    && wget -O /tmp/chromedriver.zip https://chromedriver.storage.googleapis.com/$CHROME_DRIVER_VERSION/chromedriver_linux64.zip \
    && unzip /tmp/chromedriver.zip chromedriver -d /usr/local/bin/

# Set up working directory
WORKDIR /app

# Copy test files
COPY target/test-automation.jar app.jar
COPY src/test/resources/testng.xml testng.xml

# Set environment variables
ENV CHROME_DRIVER_PATH=/usr/local/bin/chromedriver
ENV TEST_ENVIRONMENT=docker

# Run tests
CMD ["java", "-jar", "app.jar", "-testng", "testng.xml"]

---

# docker-compose.yml for Selenium Grid
version: '3'
services:
  selenium-hub:
    image: selenium/hub:latest
    container_name: selenium-hub
    ports:
      - "4444:4444"
    environment:
      - GRID_MAX_SESSION=16
      - GRID_BROWSER_TIMEOUT=300
      - GRID_TIMEOUT=300
    networks:
      - selenium-grid
  
  chrome-node:
    image: selenium/node-chrome:latest
    container_name: chrome-node
    depends_on:
      - selenium-hub
    environment:
      - HUB_HOST=selenium-hub
      - HUB_PORT=4444
      - NODE_MAX_INSTANCES=5
      - NODE_MAX_SESSION=5
    volumes:
      - /dev/shm:/dev/shm
    networks:
      - selenium-grid
    scale: 3
  
  firefox-node:
    image: selenium/node-firefox:latest
    container_name: firefox-node
    depends_on:
      - selenium-hub
    environment:
      - HUB_HOST=selenium-hub
      - HUB_PORT=4444
      - NODE_MAX_INSTANCES=5
      - NODE_MAX_SESSION=5
    volumes:
      - /dev/shm:/dev/shm
    networks:
      - selenium-grid
    scale: 2
  
  test-runner:
    build: .
    container_name: test-runner
    depends_on:
      - selenium-hub
      - chrome-node
      - firefox-node
    environment:
      - SELENIUM_HUB_URL=http://selenium-hub:4444/wd/hub
      - TEST_SUITE=smoke
    volumes:
      - ./reports:/app/reports
      - ./screenshots:/app/screenshots
    networks:
      - selenium-grid

networks:
  selenium-grid:
    driver: bridge

---

# Kubernetes Deployment
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: selenium-hub
  namespace: qa-automation
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: selenium-hub
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: selenium-hub
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: selenium-hub
        image: selenium/hub:latest
        ports:
        - containerPort: 4444
        env:
        - name: GRID_MAX_SESSION
          value: "20"
        - name: GRID_BROWSER_TIMEOUT
          value: "300"
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "512Mi"
            cpu: "250m"
          limits:
            memory: "1Gi"
            cpu: "500m"
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: selenium-hub-service
  namespace: qa-automation
spec:
  selector:
    app: selenium-hub
  ports:
  - port: 4444
    targetPort: 4444
  type: ClusterIP
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: chrome-node
  namespace: qa-automation
spec:
  replicas: 5
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: chrome-node
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: chrome-node
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: chrome-node
        image: selenium/node-chrome:latest
        env:
        - name: HUB_HOST
          value: "selenium-hub-service"
        - name: HUB_PORT
          value: "4444"
        - name: NODE_MAX_INSTANCES
          value: "1"
        - name: NODE_MAX_SESSION
          value: "1"
        volumeMounts:
        - name: dshm
          mountPath: /dev/shm
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "1Gi"
            cpu: "500m"
          limits:
            memory: "2Gi"
            cpu: "1000m"
      volumes:
      - name: dshm
        emptyDir:
          medium: Memory
          sizeLimit: 2Gi
---
apiVersion: batch/v1
kind: Job
metadata:
  name: selenium-test-job
  namespace: qa-automation
spec:
  template:
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: test-runner
        image: qa-automation:latest
        env:
        - name: SELENIUM_HUB_URL
          value: "http://selenium-hub-service:4444/wd/hub"
        - name: TEST_SUITE
          value: "regression"
        - name: PARALLEL_COUNT
          value: "5"
        volumeMounts:
        - name: test-results
          mountPath: /app/reports
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "512Mi"
            cpu: "250m"
          limits:
            memory: "1Gi"
            cpu: "500m"
      restartPolicy: Never
      volumes:
      - name: test-results
        persistentVolumeClaim:
          claimName: test-results-pvc
  backoffLimit: 3

questions.question: How do you implement Infrastructure as Code (IaC) for test environments using Terraform?
questions.answer: Terraform IaC for test environments involves defining cloud infrastructure in declarative configuration files, managing environment provisioning/destruction, implementing environment-specific variables, and integrating with CI/CD pipelines for automated environment management. This ensures consistent, repeatable, and version-controlled test environments.

questions.question: How do you implement monitoring and alerting for automated test execution?
questions.answer: Test monitoring involves collecting metrics from test execution (pass/fail rates, execution time, resource usage), setting up dashboards for visibility, configuring alerts for failures and performance degradation, and implementing log aggregation for debugging. Tools include Grafana, Prometheus, ELK Stack, and custom dashboards.
questions.code:
# docker-compose.yml for Monitoring Stack
version: '3.8'
services:
  # Prometheus for metrics collection
  prometheus:
    image: prom/prometheus:latest
    container_name: prometheus
    ports:
      - "9090:9090"
    volumes:
      - ./prometheus.yml:/etc/prometheus/prometheus.yml
      - prometheus_data:/prometheus
    command:
      - '--config.file=/etc/prometheus/prometheus.yml'
      - '--storage.tsdb.path=/prometheus'
      - '--web.console.libraries=/usr/share/prometheus/console_libraries'
      - '--web.console.templates=/usr/share/prometheus/consoles'
      - '--web.enable-lifecycle'
    networks:
      - monitoring

  # Grafana for dashboards
  grafana:
    image: grafana/grafana:latest
    container_name: grafana
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    environment:
      - GF_SECURITY_ADMIN_PASSWORD=admin123
    volumes:
      - grafana_data:/var/lib/grafana
      - ./grafana/dashboards:/var/lib/grafana/dashboards
      - ./grafana/provisioning:/etc/grafana/provisioning
    networks:
      - monitoring

  # Elasticsearch for log storage
  elasticsearch:
    image: docker.elastic.co/elasticsearch/elasticsearch:7.14.0
    container_name: elasticsearch
    environment:
      - discovery.type=single-node
      - "ES_JAVA_OPTS=-Xms512m -Xmx512m"
    ports:
      - "9200:9200"
    volumes:
      - elasticsearch_data:/usr/share/elasticsearch/data
    networks:
      - monitoring

  # Kibana for log visualization
  kibana:
    image: docker.elastic.co/kibana/kibana:7.14.0
    container_name: kibana
    ports:
      - "5601:5601"
    environment:
      - ELASTICSEARCH_HOSTS=http://elasticsearch:9200
    depends_on:
      - elasticsearch
    networks:
      - monitoring

  # Logstash for log processing
  logstash:
    image: docker.elastic.co/logstash/logstash:7.14.0
    container_name: logstash
    volumes:
      - ./logstash/pipeline:/usr/share/logstash/pipeline
    environment:
      - "LS_JAVA_OPTS=-Xmx256m -Xms256m"
    ports:
      - "5044:5044"
    depends_on:
      - elasticsearch
    networks:
      - monitoring

  # AlertManager for alerting
  alertmanager:
    image: prom/alertmanager:latest
    container_name: alertmanager
    ports:
      - "9093:9093"
    volumes:
      - ./alertmanager.yml:/etc/alertmanager/alertmanager.yml
    networks:
      - monitoring

questions.question: How do you implement GitOps workflows for test automation deployments?
questions.answer: GitOps for test automation involves using Git as the single source of truth for infrastructure and application configurations, implementing automated deployments based on Git commits, using ArgoCD or Flux for Kubernetes deployments, and maintaining environment parity through declarative configurations. This ensures version-controlled, auditable, and automated test environment management.
questions.code:
# .github/workflows/gitops-test-deployment.yml
name: GitOps Test Deployment

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
      - develop
    paths:
      - 'k8s/**'
      - 'test-automation/**'
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - main
    paths:
      - 'k8s/**'
      - 'test-automation/**'

env:
  REGISTRY: ghcr.io
  IMAGE_NAME: ${{ github.repository }}/test-automation

jobs:
  build-and-push:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    
    steps:
    - name: Checkout repository
      uses: actions/checkout@v3
    
    - name: Set up Docker Buildx
      uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v2
    
    - name: Log in to Container Registry
      uses: docker/login-action@v2
      with:
        registry: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}
        username: ${{ github.actor }}
        password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
    
    - name: Extract metadata
      id: meta
      uses: docker/metadata-action@v4
      with:
        images: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}/${{ env.IMAGE_NAME }}
        tags: |
          type=ref,event=branch
          type=ref,event=pr
          type=sha,prefix={{branch}}-
          type=raw,value=latest,enable={{is_default_branch}}
    
    - name: Build and push Docker image
      uses: docker/build-push-action@v3
      with:
        context: ./test-automation
        push: true
        tags: ${{ steps.meta.outputs.tags }}
        labels: ${{ steps.meta.outputs.labels }}
        cache-from: type=gha
        cache-to: type=gha,mode=max
